Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Organizational Production of Earnings Inequalities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1528294
Donald Tomaskovic-Devey
University of Massachusetts Amherst

SES-1524787
Dustin Avent-Holt
University of California-Irvine

SES-1524761
Andrew Penner
Georgia Regents University

Rising income inequality is a widespread problem in high income countries. While the broad trajectories of national income and wealth inequalities are apparent, little is known about the workplace and institutional dynamics that produce these disturbing trends. This project investigates the dynamics of workplace earnings distributions, a major component of the overall income distribution. The researchers will take advantage of available administrative data on nearly all private sector workplaces and their employees for six countries over fifteen years to examine workplace level inequality levels and trends. The research centers on two central questions: What factors drive overall income inequality in workplaces? How do workplaces exacerbate or mitigate the impact of individual distinctions, such as education level, gender or immigrant status? The unique comparative population level data design allows the research team to address these two questions in both cross- and sub-national temporal contexts, asking: How do inequality generating mechanisms vary as a function of institutional context? Policy debates about inequality primarily focus on government redistribution at the national level, often ignoring that income distributions have become more unequal because of workplace compensation shifts.

The study brings workplaces into the center of the analysis of national inequality levels and trajectories. Current policy discussions often ignore the role of national institutions and workplace practices in encouraging or discouraging inequality outcomes. Building on Relational Inequality Theory the project examines the generic social mechanisms that produce both levels and distributions of organizational incomes and the degree to which they are moderated by institutional context. Combining Linked Employer-Employee Panel (LEEP) data with local institutional knowledge the research analyses data on virtually all employees linked to all employers in the private sector for six countries with high quality LEEP data: Germany, France, Sweden, Norway, Slovenia and the Czech Republic, from circa 2000 to the present. This study helps uncover the potential for interventions via educational investments, equal opportunity enforcement, wage floors and ceilings, and other institutional interventions that influence organizational variation in inequalities. Better understanding and documenting why some firms produce less inequality than others will provide a powerful counter-narrative to the idea that inequality is a naturally occurring process. Exploring organizational variation within and between countries will reveal the range of inequality regimes compatible with contemporary product and labor market constraints. Further, by linking gender and ethnic/citizenship inequalities to the structure of workplace inequality dynamics study results may reveal new paths for increasing social inclusion of historically marginalized groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined how organizations shape a variety of workplace inequalities. Our team worked with administrative data linking individuals to their employers in 15 different countries (Canada, Czechia, Denmark, France, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Israel, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Slovenia, South Korea, Sweden, and the United States). This involved building a network of 30 social scientists using these data across sociology, economics, and business. Bringing together such a broad range of countries enabled us to document variation both in the extent of inequality and in how it is structured by organizations.

In empirically observing the role of organizations in generating inequality, our analyses documented that the primary driver of growing earnings inequalities in most countries is the growth of inequality between organizations. Growing earnings inequality is a significant political problem across most developed countries, but little previous research has been able to examine how firms shape this in different countries. We found that organizations have diverged, with some becoming high wage organizations while others have become low wage organizations. This polarization of earnings across organizations occurred in 13 of the 15 countries we analyzed, underscoring that policies addressing earnings inequality should consider factors like the hiring and remuneration processes of organizations.

The hiring and remuneration processes of organizations are also central to the gender pay gap, and we provided for the first time a comparison of the gender pay gap across countries that accounts for the role of organizations and occupations. Most international research looks at the gender pay gap at the country level, and when possible accounts for occupations. However, research that is able to examine the more detailed level of jobs within organizations has found in the US and a few other countries that most of the gender pay gap is driven by men and women working in different jobs. However, looking across 14 of these countries we find this is not uniformly true. In many countries there are substantial differences in pay between women and men doing the same work for the same employer. Policies seeking to promote gender equality should thus focus not only on the hiring and promotion practices that sort women and men into different jobs, but also on practices related to paying employees within a particular job.

By bringing together 30 social scientists from a range of disciplines, career stages, and countries this project has created a vibrant network of scholars. We expect that this network will continue to produce cutting edge research using administrative data on a wide range of contemporary employment issues.  Continuing work in the COIN project includes research on gender dynamics in Eastern European countries, growing income segregation between workplaces in fourteen countries, workplace variation in citizen-native wage gaps in eight countries, the impact of workplace precarity on gender wage gaps in Korea and the Netherlands, studies of mobility between workplaces in Demark, and the determinants of organizational inequality trajectories in  a four country (Denmark, Israel, Germany, Japan). Projects have received funding from national governments in Germany, Norway, France, and the U.S. The U.S. funding came from the National Science Foundation Sociology program (SES 1852756).
